metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: PHP Form Handling
The PHP superglobals $_GET and $_POST are used to collect form-data.
content.html: The PHP superglobals $_GET and $_POST are used to collect form-data.

content.text: PHP - A Simple HTML Form
The example below displays a simple HTML form with two input fields and a submit button:
content.html: The example below displays a simple HTML form with two input fields and a submit button:

content.code:
<
html
>


<
body
>



<
form

action
=
"
welcome.php
"

method
=
"
POST
"
>

Name:
<

type
=
"

"

"
>

<

content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<form action="welcome.php" method="POST">
Name: <input type="text" name="name"><br>
E-mail: <input type="text" name="email"><br>
<input type="submit">
</form>

</body>
</html>

content.text: When the user fills out the form above and clicks the submit button, the form data is sent for processing to a PHP file named "welcome.php". The form data is sent with the HTTP POST method.
content.html: When the user fills out the form above and clicks the submit button, the form data is sent for processing to a PHP file named "welcome.php". The form data is sent with the HTTP POST method.

content.text: To display the submitted data you could simply echo all the variables.
content.html: To display the submitted data you could simply echo all the variables.

content.text: The "welcome.php" looks like this:
content.html: The "welcome.php" looks like this:

content.code:
<
html
>


<
body
>


Welcome
<?php

echo

$_POST
[
"name"
]
;

?>
<
br
>

Your email address is:
<?php

echo

$_POST
[
"email"
]
;

?>



</
body
>


</
html
>
content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

Welcome <?php echo $_POST["name"]; ?><br>
Your email address is: <?php echo $_POST["email"]; ?>

</body>
</html>

content.text: The output could be something like this:
content.html: The output could be something like this:

Welcome John
Your email address is john
.
doe@example
.
com
content.code_html:
Welcome John
Your email address is john.doe@example.com

<input type="submit">

</body>

Welcome <?php echo $_GET["name"]; ?><br>
Your email address is: <?php echo $_GET["email"]; ?>

</body>

content.text: The code above is quite simple, and it does not include any validation.
content.html: The code above is quite simple, and it does not include any validation.

content.text: You need to validate form data to protect your script from malicious code.
content.html: You need to validate form data to protect your script from malicious code.

content.text: Think SECURITY when processing PHP forms!
content.html: Think SECURITY when processing PHP forms!

content.text: This page does not contain any form validation, it just shows how you can send and retrieve form data.
content.html: This page does not contain any form validation, it just shows how you can send and retrieve form data.

content.text: However, the next pages will show how to process PHP forms with security in mind! Proper validation of form data is important to protect your form from hackers and spammers!
content.html: However, the next pages will show how to process PHP forms with security in mind! Proper validation of form data is important to protect your form from hackers and spammers!

content.text: GET vs. POST

Both GET and POST create an array (e.g. array( key1 => value1, key2 => value2, key3 => value3, ...)). This array holds key/value pairs, where keys are the names of the form controls and values are the input data from the user.
content.html: Both GET and POST create an array (e.g. array( key1 => value1, key2 => value2, key3 => value3, ...)). This array holds key/value pairs, where keys are the names of the form controls and values are the input data from the user.

content.text: Both GET and POST are treated as $_GET and $_POST. These are superglobals, which means that they are always accessible, regardless of scope - and you can access them from any function, class or file without having to do anything special.
content.html: Both GET and POST are treated as $_GET and $_POST. These are superglobals, which means that they are always accessible, regardless of scope - and you can access them from any function, class or file without having to do anything special.

content.text: $_GET is an array of variables passed to the current script via the URL parameters.
content.html: $_GET is an array of variables passed to the current script via the URL parameters.

content.text: $_POST is an array of variables passed to the current script via the HTTP POST method.
content.html: $_POST is an array of variables passed to the current script via the HTTP POST method.

content.text: When to use GET?

Information sent from a form with the GET method is visible to everyone (all variable names and values are displayed in the URL). GET also has limits on the amount of information to send. The limitation is about 2000 characters. However, because the variables are displayed in the URL, it is possible to bookmark the page. This can be useful in some cases.
content.html: Information sent from a form with the GET method is visible to everyone (all variable names and values are displayed in the URL). GET also has limits on the amount of information to send. The limitation is about 2000 characters. However, because the variables are displayed in the URL, it is possible to bookmark the page. This can be useful in some cases.

content.text: GET may be used for sending non-sensitive data.
content.html: GET may be used for sending non-sensitive data.

content.text: Note: GET should NEVER be used for sending passwords or other sensitive information!
content.html: Note: GET should NEVER be used for sending passwords or other sensitive information!

content.text: When to use POST?
Information sent from a form with the POST method is invisible to others (all names/values are embedded within the body of the HTTP request) and has no limits on the amount of information to send.
content.html: Information sent from a form with the POST method is invisible to others (all names/values are embedded within the body of the HTTP request) and has no limits on the amount of information to send.

content.text: Moreover POST supports advanced functionality such as support for multi-part binary input while uploading files to server.
content.html: Moreover POST supports advanced functionality such as support for multi-part binary input while uploading files to server.

content.text: However, because the variables are not displayed in the URL, it is not possible to bookmark the page.
content.html: However, because the variables are not displayed in the URL, it is not possible to bookmark the page.

content.text: Developers prefer POST for sending form data.
content.html: Developers prefer POST for sending form data.

content.text: Next, lets see how we can process PHP forms the secure way!
content.html: Next, lets see how we can process PHP forms the secure way!

What HTML attribute is used to specify the HTTP method of a form?
content.html: What HTML attribute is used to specify the HTTP method of a form?
